#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Make Art Work Inspired by Autumn
#Text=A crisp , sunny , day in fall is a perfect time to get outdoors and take in nature ’s beauty .
#Text=For those able to take an actual walk , being outside is sure to awaken your senses and powers of observation .
#Text=Once inside again , drawing and painting what you have seen during this special , colorful season is a good way to remember your day .
#Text=If your art abilities or confidence are minimal , not to worry .
#Text=Doing a collage of pictures of things you might encounter on a fall walk is just as creative and fun .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Finding Inspiration
#Text=Brainstorm the words “ fall ” and “ autumn ” for ideas .
#Text=List the words that come to mind on sketch paper .
#Text=A sketchbook is a good place to record your thoughts .
#Text=With a sketchbook , you can review your impressions again and again , as often as you like .
#Text=Sketchbooks come in all shapes , sizes and prices .
#Text=They are readily available at many stores , from the discount mart to a pharmacy or , for fancier choices , try a store that sells art materials .
#Text=Try brainstorming as a group .
#Text=As an alternative , for larger groups , write words and ideas on a poster board , or chalkboard .
#Text=Ask the participants to call out ideas of what they might encounter on a fall walk .
#Text=Use bold marker , print large and create a reference for all to see .
#Text=Commonly seen things include :

#Text=Trees and colored leaves , fall flowers , Black eyed Susans , goldenrod , apples , wild flowers , pumpkin displays , pumpkins on the vine , bare trees and naked branches , Queen Anne ’s lace , cattails , gourds , squash , Chinese lanterns , bittersweet branches , nuts in the shell , mums , baskets and displays of harvested garden produce .
#Text=Farm things , haystacks , corn stalks tied to a pole , round hay bales , apples , a bonfire , clouds , scarecrows , fences , a rake with piles of leaves
#Text=Creatures such as owls , squirrels , raccoons , ducks , geese , geese on the wing , mice , birds rising all together out of dead bushes or brush , etc.
#Text=Warm clothing , plaid flannel shirts , hiking boots , hats , gloves , long johns , kids playing in the leaves , people walking dogs , etc.
#Text=Assemble your mark-making art materials .
#Text=These supplies can be as simple as a box of crayons , #2 yellow pencil , eraser and black fine line marker to -- -sets of varied types of marking devices .
#Text=Each offers ease of use and loads of fun .
#Text=The sky ’s the limit !
#Text=Set out items from what you already own before taking a trip to the store to accumulate new ones .
#Text=Gather your watercolor materials .
#Text=A basic 8-color set of dry pigments from the discount store will work , but for richer colors that are smoother to apply , invest in a nicer set .
#Text=Tube paints need a palette to hold them and blank spaces for mixing .
#Text=Any type of watercolor will work .
#Text=The final step will be to add color , as much or as little as you want .
#Text=Making a Fall Collage
#Text=Find fall themed images and photos in magazines , catalogs , and newspapers to substitute for needing to draw the images .
#Text=Cut and paste photos from these publications to make a fall collage .
#Text=Purchase magazines second hand at the library or thrift store .
#Text=Take your own photos .
#Text=Go through what you ’ve already taken , make prints or photocopies and assemble a store of possible imagery .
#Text=The free-stock photo sharing sites on the internet are also a good source for pictures .
#Text=Print out your favorites .
#Text=Look at the sites that offer coloring pages to copy and print out .
#Text=These black and white drawings are excellent material for cutting and pasting .
#Text=Cut out many images that appeal to you .
#Text=Place them on a sheet of heavy paper and rearrange them until you have a design that speaks to you .
#Text=Glue them down using a glue stick , being careful to get all the edges flat and adhered to the paper .
#Text=Use markers and/or watercolor or acrylic or poster paint to pull the piece together .
#Text=Making a Fall Drawing
#Text=Draw your path .
#Text=Start right off , at the beginning , on a blank sheet with a double line to represent your path .
#Text=Have it be a path that meanders through your page .
#Text=Keep it simple if you wish .
#Text=No need to be elaborate when a stick figure or simple shape can be used to tell your autumn walk adventures .
#Text=Start by drawing one small thing , for example , a tree .
#Text=Add another and another thing , such as a scarecrow , hay bales or some geese , no need to worry about correct or rigid placement of these items , scatter them over your paper .
#Text=If unsure how to draw something , trace it .
#Text=Use colored drawing media if you wish .
#Text=Colored markers , pencils , crayons , or any of the interesting sticks available for drawing in color .
#Text=Be adventurous and have fun experimenting with new materials .
#Text=Paint as you go or after your drawing is complete .
#Text=Check for ways to pull the whole thing together .
#Text=Unify your work .
#Text=Repeat a motif such as an autumn leaf , a vine , a color , repeated throughout .
#Text=Black lines made with a marker will often work .
#Text=Find ways to join and link things .
#Text=Hang up your work to enjoy .
#Text=When you feel a need to commune with nature , just look at your artwork and take a walk with your eyes through nature that you ’ve put on the page .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If you have used heavy watercolor paper , do n’t hesitate to glue on small items such as pretty , colorful leaves , petals , greenery , nut or seed pods .
#Text=For heavier items you might need white glue , with time to let it dry flat , or a hot glue gun to adhere them .
